title: How should one start a career in photography? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ah yes the photography business… It is a very difficult and saturated industry to get into but that doesn’t mean you shouldn’t pursue your passions. It’s a very rewarding business if you know how to brand yourself. Here is how I built my photography business when I was 16 years old and continue to build now that I am 20. You need to be doing free work my friend. This (in my opinion) is the fastest way to grow your business and be successful in the long run. Here is what I’ve found. So many people (photographers) charge crazy low prices because they think that’s what their customers want. You get what you ask for. Rather than get valuable clients that are going to solely book you when they need a photoshoot, you are getting people that just want to pay the lowest price and don’t really care who the photographer is. By charging a higher price, you get people (usually with higher incomes) that are willing to pay that hefty price for a quality service they can trust. Now these clients are who you want to be booking. So how do you get these high paying clients? What you need to do is build trust. You NEED an outstanding portfolio that really shows why you’re worth that much. Why do photographers pay thousands of dollars on Nikon equipment and stick with that brand (or other brands)? It’s because Nikon has proven over and over again that they only have high quality products. They have a track record and can show you what the cameras produce. Say a new camera company comes out today. The wrong move would be to make a random website and social media page, and charge thousands of dollars for a product that no one knows about. The right move would be to hand out ten cameras and let the photographers try them out, receiving feedback in the process. Then posting other people using the cameras (social proof) on your social media and website showing how awesome the product is. This is exactly what you need to do for your photography business. Don’t try to undercut photographers because not only do you look unprofessional but you are damaging your brand by telling people you don’t know your worth! So First thing is free work building your portfolio. Now what you are going to do is pick a specific niche. Now I’m not talking about just saying you’re a wedding photographer or you do corporate photoshoots. We really need to find that super tiny crack that we are going to fill. For me, I shoot Adventure Engagements. I take couples around to different National Parks and deliver awesome portraits with beautiful landscapes in the background. To my amazement, I found that when I buckled down on my niche, turning clients away that didn't fall into my category, I began to attract a huge crowd of people that wanted to book my service just due to that fact that I only shoot outdoor adventure engagement shoots! So really choose what you want to go into. It can be in the food industry or even first birthdays for a specific gender. You will find that people are willing to pay astronomical prices when you are an expert in a specific niche. That’s how I am able to charge $1000/ session and be booked the whole summer! Keep in mind that this is a business and if you build it right, it’s going to take time. I started out by doing free photoshoots. I worked free for nearly a year before I was able to charge. First of all, I was not the best photographer at first and wasn’t comfortable and confident enough to charge, and second I really wanted to build up my portfolio to have a solid foundation. Building a photography business nowadays goes way beyond just being a good photographer. It involves building a website (that will actually popup when someone searches it), building an audience, knowing how to advertise… it gets real detailed my friend but it’s worth the learning curve. There are a few more steps to this business building process on the back end including advertising, networking, building a converting website, what photography gear to get (from a minimalists perspective) and other key factors you need to take into consideration. I teach all this stuff in my blog (link in profile). Stop by and send me a message too. I’d love to help build this so us creatives can thrive!

Photography is an art, and when passion meets art, there’s no better synergy. If you see something picture-perfect and wish to capture the image and share it with the world, it speaks volumes about your passion for photography. A picture speaks a thousand words, and your pictures can change the way people look at the world. Who knows, your passion may even become your career Graphic designers, illustrators, and professional photographers all began their creative journeys by realising their passions. If you’ve decided that photography is what moves you, read on to find out what you can do to make your dreams come true. The transition into a professional photography career can be intimidating, but with research and passion behind you as a driving force, it’s absolutely possible. Here are a few tips and suggestions on how you can make the leap from a hobby photographer to professional photographer and start doing what you love full-time by making a career in photography: Get prepared: Getting prepared to make that leap means preparing your life for incidents, in case the jump into professional photography doesn’t work out. Make sure you’ve purchased all the equipment you need before you commit full-time  Know your camera: While you try your hand at photography in an attempt to express yourself, your camera will be your best teacher. Know your tools and build your skills bit by bit Get the right exposure: Before you consider photography as a career option, know your skills in and out. Photography has a wide range of branches you can pursue, depending on what kind of photos you wish to click and why. Research and pick a course that you think has the scope to give you what you want, in terms of knowledgeMarket your business: Make sure your website, portfolio, and social media accounts are all up-to-date with your best work and ready for client exploration. Work on a media kit for yourself, with email pitches you can use to get clients, provide price-sheets, and referencesLine up some contracts: If you’ve been shooting part-time, this is a great way to start building a client list and informing them of your availabilities for more projects when you do go full-time. Start pitching to clients and sending introductions before you commit. Knowing you have a project scheduled for the future can validate your leap into a full-time photography careerGo freelancing (if it works in your favour)!: Most aspiring photographers today opt for freelance photography as it offers flexibility and convenience. Instead of binding yourself to just one field of photography as a career, it’s best to keep your options open and experiment with different concepts and themes for shoots and projects Focus on long-term career goals: While apps like Instagram and Facebook are currently fantastic marketing tools for photographers to showcase their work to potential clients and audiences, don’t forget to think about building a sustainable career offline.Make a long-term plan on what you want to accomplish in your photography career, outside of the platforms you hope to do it on. Make plans on how you will grow your photography business, and master your photography skills. You don’t want to put all your eggs in one basket because the realities are you have little control on whether that app, website or social media platform succeeds or fails. If the industry changes, you want to be recognized in other photography communities Know the realities of being a professional photographer: You have to be extremely aware of what it really takes to be a professional photographer, and okay with the struggles. There can be some stress and pressure that comes with waiting for the next job. You need to be extremely organized because unless you are with an agency you will be responsible for managing your finances, invoices, taxes, and scheduling. You have to be a little ready to go on the fly, a job might come up and require to pack your bags within the hour.When photography is only a hobby, you don’t really have those pressures. You just take photographs for the love of the craft. But, if you can master all of these potential roadblocks, you’ll be turning something you love into a viable full-time career. That makes the struggles worth it
